Práce a byznys.czech: pustit se do práce, jít k věci
Práce a byznys.sentence: Let's stop chatting and get down to business.

Práce a byznys.czech: šetřit na úkor kvality, dělat něco narychlo
Práce a byznys.sentence: They cut corners on safety, and now they're facing problems.

Práce a byznys.czech: naučit se, jak to chodí (v nové práci/situaci)
Práce a byznys.sentence: It took him a few weeks to learn the ropes of his new job.
As the manager, she calls the shots in this department.
We need to think outside the box to solve this complex problem.
You have to be on the ball to succeed in this competitive industry.
He had to burn the midnight oil to finish the report on time.

Práce a byznys.czech: začít s něčím s plnou vervou, bez otálení
Práce a byznys.sentence: The new employee really hit the ground running.
She works hard to bring home the bacon for her family.

Práce a byznys.czech: udělat něco navíc, vynaložit extra úsilí
Práce a byznys.sentence: Our team always goes the extra mile for our clients.

Práce a byznys.czech: změnit pravidla hry, zásadně ovlivnit situaci
Práce a byznys.sentence: This new technology is a real game changer for the industry.

Práce a byznys.english: to get your foot in the door
Práce a byznys.czech: dostat se někam, získat první příležitost
Práce a byznys.sentence: An internship is a great way to get your foot in the door at a good company.
After a tough quarter, the company was in the red.
Thanks to strong sales, we're finally in the black this month.
He had to pull some strings to get that meeting with the CEO.

Práce a byznys.english: to keep your eye on the ball
Práce a byznys.czech: dávat si pozor, soustředit se na cíl
Práce a byznys.sentence: It's important to keep your eye on the ball during negotiations.

Práce a byznys.english: to put all your eggs in one basket
Práce a byznys.sentence: It's risky to put all your eggs in one basket; diversify your investments.
Don't try to pass the buck; you're responsible for this project.

Každodenní konverzace.sentence: Don't spill the beans about the surprise party!
I had to bite the bullet and work extra hours to finish the project.
Before your performance, I just wanted to say, 'break a leg!'

Každodenní konverzace.english: to cost an arm and a leg
Každodenní konverzace.sentence: That designer bag must have cost an arm and a leg.

Každodenní konverzace.english: to get something off your chest
Každodenní konverzace.sentence: I need to talk to you; I have something I need to get off my chest.
It's getting late, we should hit the road.

Každodenní konverzace.czech: tahat někoho za nos, dělat si legraci
Každodenní konverzace.sentence: Are you serious, or are you just pulling my leg?
You've been working too hard, you should take it easy this weekend.

Každodenní konverzace.english: to be a piece of cake
Každodenní konverzace.sentence: The test was a piece of cake.
Stop beating around the bush and tell me what you really think.
The party got a little out of hand.
I know it's tough, but hang in there; it'll get better.

Každodenní konverzace.english: to hit the nail on the head
Každodenní konverzace.sentence: You hit the nail on the head with that observation.

Každodenní konverzace.english: to let the cat out of the bag
Každodenní konverzace.sentence: She accidentally let the cat out of the bag about the surprise.

Každodenní konverzace.english: to make a long story short
Každodenní konverzace.sentence: To make a long story short, we decided to move.

Každodenní konverzace.english: to bite off more than you can chew
Každodenní konverzace.sentence: He bit off more than he could chew with this project.

Vztahy a emoce.sentence: After their argument, they met to clear the air.

Vztahy a emoce.english: to have a soft spot for someone
Vztahy a emoce.sentence: He's always had a soft spot for stray animals.
My brother and I don't always see eye to eye on politics.
His constant whistling is really getting on my nerves.
After years of feuding, they finally decided to bury the hatchet.

Vztahy a emoce.english: to have a heart of gold
Vztahy a emoce.sentence: She's always helping others; she truly has a heart of gold.

Vztahy a emoce.english: to wear your heart on your sleeve
Vztahy a emoce.czech: mít srdce na dlani, dávat najevo emoce
Vztahy a emoce.sentence: He wears his heart on his sleeve, so you always know how he feels.
It's important to get along with your colleagues.

Vztahy a emoce.czech: být na tenkém ledě, v nebezpečí
Vztahy a emoce.sentence: He's on thin ice with his girlfriend after forgetting her birthday.
The teacher decided to turn a blind eye to the small infraction.

Vztahy a emoce.english: to give someone the cold shoulder
Vztahy a emoce.czech: chovat se k někomu chladně, ignorovat někoho
Vztahy a emoce.sentence: After their fight, she gave him the cold shoulder.

Vztahy a emoce.english: to have a bone to pick with someone
Vztahy a emoce.czech: mít s někým nevyřízené účty, chtít si s někým promluvit o problému
Vztahy a emoce.sentence: I have a bone to pick with you about what you said yesterday.

Vztahy a emoce.english: to rub someone the wrong way
Vztahy a emoce.czech: lézt někomu na nervy, dráždit někoho
Vztahy a emoce.sentence: His arrogant attitude really rubs me the wrong way.

Vztahy a emoce.english: to be in someone's good books
Vztahy a emoce.sentence: I'm trying to be in my boss's good books before my performance review.

Problémy a řešení.sentence: He's in hot water with his boss after missing the deadline.
The last-minute donation saved the day for the charity.

Problémy a řešení.english: to be out of the woods
Problémy a řešení.sentence: The patient is still recovering, but he's finally out of the woods.
After breaking the window, he had to face the music and tell his parents.

Problémy a řešení.czech: hodit ručník do ringu, vzdát se
Problémy a řešení.sentence: After several attempts, she decided to throw in the towel.

Problémy a řešení.english: to be a blessing in disguise
Problémy a řešení.sentence: Losing that job was a blessing in disguise; it led me to a better opportunity.

Problémy a řešení.english: to get to the bottom of something
Problémy a řešení.czech: přijít něčemu na kloub, zjistit pravdu
Problémy a řešení.sentence: We need to get to the bottom of why this error occurred.

Problémy a řešení.english: to nip something in the bud
Problémy a řešení.sentence: It's better to nip the problem in the bud before it gets worse.
To make matters worse, it started raining just as we left.
The IT team had to put out a fire with the server crash.

Problémy a řešení.english: to be between a rock and a hard place
Problémy a řešení.czech: být mezi mlýnskými kameny, být v neřešitelné situaci
Problémy a řešení.sentence: He was between a rock and a hard place, unable to choose either option.

Problémy a řešení.english: to be up a creek without a paddle
Problémy a řešení.czech: být v úzkých, být v beznadějné situaci
Problémy a řešení.sentence: If we lose this client, we'll be up a creek without a paddle.
We hit a snag when the supplier couldn't deliver the parts on time.
The new marketing strategy helped to turn the tide for the struggling company.

Problémy a řešení.english: to sweep something under the rug
Problémy a řešení.czech: zamést něco pod koberec, zatajit problém
Problémy a řešení.sentence: They tried to sweep the scandal under the rug, but it eventually came out.

Rozhodování a názory.sentence: He's still sitting on the fence about which university to choose.
I was going to go, but I've changed my mind.

Rozhodování a názory.english: to be on the same page
Rozhodování a názory.sentence: Before we start, let's make sure we're all on the same page.

Rozhodování a názory.czech: hrát ďáblova advokáta (argumentovat proti něčemu, aby se prozkoumaly všechny aspekty)
Rozhodování a názory.sentence: I'll play devil's advocate for a moment and suggest an alternative.
It's time to make up your mind about what you want to do.
I'm having second thoughts about buying that expensive car.
Before making a decision, you should weigh your options carefully.

Rozhodování a názory.czech: zaujmout stanovisko, postavit se za něco
Rozhodování a názory.sentence: It's important to take a stand on issues you believe in.
I'm of two minds about whether to accept the job offer.
We couldn't come to an agreement, so we decided to agree to disagree.
As the team leader, she calls the shots on this project.

Rozhodování a názory.czech: mít slovo, mít možnost se vyjádřit
Rozhodování a názory.sentence: Everyone should have a say in how decisions are made.
Don't jump to conclusions; let's wait for all the facts.

Čas a plánování.sentence: We're working against the clock to finish this project by Friday.
We're running out of time to catch our flight.
We had to kill time at the airport waiting for our plane.

Čas a plánování.english: to be ahead of your time
Čas a plánování.sentence: His inventions were truly ahead of their time.

Čas a plánování.english: to make up for lost time
Čas a plánování.sentence: After being sick, she had to work hard to make up for lost time.
I'm a bit pressed for time, so can we make this quick?
If only we could turn back the clock and fix our mistakes.
We arrived at the station just in time to catch the train.
He tried to buy time by pretending his computer crashed.
We're short on time, so let's get straight to the point.
Doctors raced against time to find a cure for the rare disease.
Don't rush; take your time and do it right.
The construction project is unfortunately behind schedule.
Good news, we are still on schedule to launch next month.

Škola a studium.sentence: I have a big exam tomorrow, so I need to hit the books tonight.
She studied hard and passed her exams with flying colors.

Škola a studium.english: to burn the candle at both ends
Škola a studium.sentence: He's burning the candle at both ends, studying all night and working all day.
You need to learn these vocabulary words by heart.

Škola a studium.czech: udělat test s přehledem, na výbornou
Škola a studium.sentence: She was confident she would ace the math test.
I had to pull an all-nighter to finish my essay.
My sister is a real bookworm; she reads constantly.
He got in trouble for cutting class too often.
I just hope I can study enough to get a passing grade.
She worked hard throughout university to graduate with honors.

Škola a studium.czech: trefit se, splnit cíl (např. na testu)
Škola a studium.sentence: His answer hit the mark and earned him full points.

Peníze a finance.sentence: It's hard to make ends meet with the rising cost of living.
Buying that new car would really break the bank.

Peníze a finance.czech: koupat se v penězích, být velmi bohatý
Peníze a finance.sentence: After selling his company, he's rolling in money.

Peníze a finance.english: to be worth your weight in gold
Peníze a finance.czech: mít cenu zlata, být k nezaplacení
Peníze a finance.sentence: Our new assistant is worth her weight in gold.
With the economy slowing down, many families have to tighten their belts.

Peníze a finance.english: to live from hand to mouth
Peníze a finance.czech: žít z ruky do úst, mít sotva na živobytí
Peníze a finance.sentence: Many people in developing countries live from hand to mouth.
I found this old furniture at a yard sale, it was dirt cheap.
We had to pay through the nose for tickets during the peak season.

Peníze a finance.czech: mít hluboko do kapsy, mít nouzi o peníze
Peníze a finance.sentence: I can't go out tonight, I'm a bit strapped for cash.
He made a killing on the stock market last year.
After payday, she was flush with cash and went shopping.
My company agreed to foot the bill for my business trip.

Popis osob a chování.sentence: He spends all weekend being a couch potato, watching TV.

Popis osob a chování.english: to have a chip on one's shoulder
Popis osob a chování.czech: mít vztek na svět, být urážlivý
Popis osob a chování.sentence: He's always complaining; he seems to have a chip on his shoulder.
My grandmother is always busy; she's a real busy bee.

Popis osob a chování.czech: přítel do pohody (který opustí v nouzi)
Popis osob a chování.sentence: He only calls when he needs something; he's a fair-weather friend.
Don't invite him to the party, he's such a wet blanket.
The kids were full of beans after the birthday cake.
He prefers to work alone; he's a bit of a lone wolf.

Popis osob a chování.czech: mít hroší kůži, být odolný vůči kritice
Popis osob a chování.sentence: You need to have a thick skin to work in customer service.
My little sister is a real chatterbox; she never stops talking.
Don't tell him your secrets; he has a big mouth.
She's a natural leader and a real people person.
Someone with sticky fingers stole my wallet.
He's a real live wire; he's always coming up with new ideas.
Be careful what you say to him; he has a short fuse.

Situace a události.sentence: The exam was a piece of cake for her.
Getting a bonus was the icing on the cake after a successful year.

Situace a události.czech: přilít olej do ohně, ještě to zhoršit
Situace a události.sentence: First, my car broke down, and then, to add insult to injury, I got a parking ticket.
Stop beating around the bush and tell me what you really think.
If you don't apply soon, you'll miss the boat on this great job.

Situace a události.english: to be a storm in a teacup
Situace a události.sentence: Their argument was just a storm in a teacup; they're friends again now.

Situace a události.czech: rozjet to, dát něco do pohybu
Situace a události.sentence: Let's get the ball rolling on this new project.
Sometimes it's easier just to go with the flow.
A good joke can often break the ice in a new group.
He's not afraid to make waves if he believes something is wrong.
The old car finally bit the dust after twenty years.
She hit the jackpot when she found a rare coin at the flea market.

Situace a události.czech: být v sedmém nebi, být nesmírně šťastný
Situace a události.sentence: After winning the championship, the team was on cloud nine.

Situace a události.czech: dovědět se o něčem, dostat echo
Situace a události.sentence: The police got wind of the plan and prevented the crime.

Situace a události.czech: být v plném proudu, v plném rozjezdu
Situace a události.sentence: The party was in full swing by the time we arrived.

Nečekané situace a náhody.sentence: Losing that job was a blessing in disguise.
He'll tidy his room? Yeah, when pigs fly.
She showed up out of the blue after years.
They got wind of the plan and canceled it.
He hit the jackpot with his lottery ticket.
The storm came out of nowhere.
I was completely caught off guard by her question.
Don't spring any surprises on me today.

Nečekané situace a náhody.english: to throw someone for a loop
Nečekané situace a náhody.sentence: His reaction really threw me for a loop.
The announcement took everyone by surprise.

Vyjádření souhlasu a nesouhlasu.english: to be on the same page
Vyjádření souhlasu a nesouhlasu.sentence: Let's make sure we're on the same page before the meeting.
His views often go against the grain.
We agreed to disagree and moved on.
We rarely see eye to eye on politics.
She took a stand against unfair treatment.
Let's meet halfway and find a solution.
I'm of two minds about this proposal.
They often butt heads over tiny details.

Vyjádření souhlasu a nesouhlasu.english: to have a bone to pick
Vyjádření souhlasu a nesouhlasu.sentence: I have a bone to pick with you.
She stood her ground despite criticism.

Humor a nadsázka.sentence: He cracked a joke during the interview.
We laughed our heads off at the movie.

Humor a nadsázka.english: to be a barrel of laughs
Humor a nadsázka.sentence: She's always a barrel of laughs.

Humor a nadsázka.english: to be a pain in the neck
Humor a nadsázka.sentence: This printer is a real pain in the neck.

His story had us in stitches.

Humor a nadsázka.english: to make a mountain out of a molehill
Humor a nadsázka.sentence: Stop making a mountain out of a molehill.
He's full of it—don’t believe him.

He laughed off the awkward moment.
